articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Drew McLellan)
articles.description: In this episode, we ask what qualities are required to introduce change in large organizations, how to convince management to do the right thing, and how to ship a billion-dollar idea. Vitaly talks to expert Paul Boag to find out.

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani)
articles.description: Letâ€™s talk about Remix, the framework to create JavaScript projects using server-side rendering. Letâ€™s go through its main features and concepts and see the similarities and differences with Next.js.
articles.title: A Look At Remix And The Differences With Next.js

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Lyndon Cerejo)
articles.description: As a designer, you may be tasked with figuring out how your company should approach the metaverse or thinking about designing for the metaverse. In this article, Lyndon Cerejo will discuss a few steps he recommends before diving headfirst into any design for the metaverse.
articles.title: A Five-Step Approach To The Metaverse

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kent Eisenhuth & Kai Chang)
articles.description: In this article, we will explore how an accessibility-first approach can lead you down the path of creating a better visual design for charts. articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)

articles.title: Designing A Perfect Pricing Page UX

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Zara Cooper)

articles.title: How To Build A Localized Website With Hugo And Strapi

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (John Scott Bowie)
articles.description: In this article, John Scott Bowie shares the story of 40 years of attempts to advance corporate UX maturity that â€” after numerous initiatives with marginal results â€” culminated in a breakthrough project that accelerated a companyâ€™s UX maturity from â€œEmergentâ€ to â€œUser-Drivenâ€ in less than a year.

articles.title: Jump Into July (2022 Desktop Wallpapers Edition)

articles.title: Smashing Podcast Episode 48 With Stephanie Eckles: Is Sass Still Relevant?

articles.title: Voice Control Usability Considerations For Partially Visually Hidden Link Names

articles.description: In this article, we will enhance the Gantt Chart component with some interaction possibilities for editing the jobs. articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sergey Krasotin)
articles.description: Looking for ways to test your product faster? In this article, Sergey Krasotin uncovers common mistakes startup product designers make that lead to longer MVP testing times. To test your product within two weeks or even less, follow these simple practices proven by Sergeyâ€™s experience with over 100 startups and accelerators.

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Vitaly Friedman)
articles.description: Do you feel stuck in your company? Do you believe you deserve a raise but it never happens? Do you think you might need to quit the job? Letâ€™s figure it out. In this article, Vitaly looks at some things he wishes heâ€™d known earlier in his career.
articles.title: Things I Wish Iâ€™d Known Earlier In My Career

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Kirill Myshkin)
articles.description: In JavaScript, itâ€™s natural to reach for timers when something is to happen on time. But when something is to happen at the exact moment because other things depend on it, you quickly learn timers are more of a problem than a solution. They are never on time, really. Web Animations API could eliminate the need for timers in certain cases while being precise.
articles.title: Precise Timing With Web Animations API

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Andrii Zhdan)
articles.description: In this article, Andrii shares his approach to managing tables in Figma in an easier, more streamlined way when there is a need to support different screen resolutions, change the order of columns, and use real-life content.

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Frederick Oâ€™Brien)

articles.title: Web Design Done Well: Delightful Data Visualization Examples

The data for rowid tables is stored as a B-Tree structure containing one entry for each table row, using the rowid value as the key. This means that retrieving or sorting records by rowid is fast. Searching for a record with a specific rowid, or for all records with rowids within a specified range is around twice as fast as a similar search made by specifying any other PRIMARY KEY or indexed value.
æ€»ç»“èµ·æ¥ï¼šrowid - ä¹Ÿå°±æ˜¯ true primary key æ€§èƒ½ä¼˜åŠ¿å¤§
åœ¨ Sqlite å®˜ç½‘çš„ rowid table ä¸­ï¼Œåˆæ˜¯è¿™ä¹ˆé˜è¿°çš„ï¼šIf the rowid is not aliased by INTEGER PRIMARY KEY then it is not persistent and might change. In particular the VACUUM command will change rowids for tables that do not declare an INTEGER PRIMARY KEY.
